title: How to Turn Off MAC Filtering

steps.title: Open the Command Prompt.
steps.content: Open the Command Prompt. You can access it from the Start menu, or by pressing ⊞ Win + R and typing cmd .

steps.title: Type .
steps.content: Type . ipconfig and press ↵ Enter .

steps.title: Find your active network connection.
steps.content: Find your active network connection. There may be several connections listed in the readout, and you may have to scroll up to find your active connection.

steps.title: Look for the .
steps.content: Look for the . Default Gateway entry. This is the address for your router. Write it down.

steps.title: Open a web browser.
steps.content: Open a web browser. You can access your router's configuration page from any web browser as long as your computer is connected to the network.

steps.title: Enter the .
steps.content: Enter the . Default Gateway address into the browser's address bar.

steps.title: Log in with your admin account.
steps.content: Log in with your admin account. Routers are protected with an admin login and password. Check your router's documentation or look up the model online to find the default login information. If you can't figure out how to log in to your router, you can reset it by pressing and holding the Reset button on the back for about 30 seconds. After the router restarts, you will be able to log in with the default admin information. Most default logins use "admin" as the username, and then "admin", "password", or a blank field as the password.

steps.title: Open the "Advanced" section and look for "MAC Filtering", "Access Control", or something similar.
steps.content: Open the "Advanced" section and look for "MAC Filtering", "Access Control", or something similar. Actually defining where the "MAC Filtering" section is located is very difficult, as the location and labeling is different for every router. Generally, you can find the "MAC Filtering" or "Access Control" settings in the "Advanced" section, though it may also be found in the "Security" or "Wireless Settings" sections. Not all routers use MAC address filtering. Some router's limit access based on static IP addresses assigned to each device.

steps.title: Disable MAC filtering.
steps.content: Disable MAC filtering. Again, the wording and location will vary depending on the router, but you will generally be able to select a "Disable" option to turn off MAC filtering. This may be a checkbox, a button or a selection that you can make.

steps.title: Save your changes.
steps.content: Save your changes. Click the "Apply" or "Save" button to save your changes to the router settings. Your router will apply the changes, which may take a few moments. If you are configuring your router over a wireless connection, you may be logged out when settings changes are saved.

steps.title: Open your Utilities folder.
steps.content: Open your Utilities folder. You can access this from the Go menu, or from your Applications folder.

steps.title: Open the AirPort Utility.
steps.content: Open the AirPort Utility. This program allows you to easily configure your AirPort router without having to use a web browser interface.

steps.title: Select your AirPort base station.
steps.content: Select your AirPort base station. If you have multiple AirPort routers installed on your network, select the one you want to make changes to and click Edit .

steps.title: Click the "Access Control" tab.
steps.content: Click the "Access Control" tab.

steps.title: Click the "MAC Address Access Control" drop-down menu and select "Not Enabled".
steps.content: Click the "MAC Address Access Control" drop-down menu and select "Not Enabled".

steps.title: Click .
steps.content: Click . Update . This will save the changes for your AirPort router, disabling MAC filtering.

steps.title: Click the Apple menu and select System Preferences.
steps.content: Click the Apple menu and select System Preferences .

steps.title: Click the Network option.
steps.content: Click the Network option.

steps.title: Select your active network adapter from the list on the left.
steps.content: Select your active network adapter from the list on the left. Connected adapters will have a green indicator next to them.

steps.title: Note the .
steps.content: Note the . Router IP Address. This is the address that you can use to access your router's settings. If you are using an AirPort router, click here.

steps.title: Enter the .
steps.content: Enter the . Router address into the browser's address bar.
